filterSets.name: Design Rules
filterSets.info: The Design Ruleset contains a collection of rules that find questionable designs.

filterSets.name: Security Code Guidelines
filterSets.info: These rules check the security guidelines from Sun, published at http://java.sun.com/security/seccodeguide.html#gcg

filterSets.name: Controversial Rules
filterSets.info: The Controversial Ruleset contains rules that, for whatever reason, are considered controversial. They are separated out here to allow people to include as they see fit via custom rulesets. This ruleset was initially created in response to discussions over UnnecessaryConstructorRule which Tom likes but most people really dislike :-)

filterSets.name: Finalizer Rules
filterSets.info: These rules deal with different problems that can occur with finalizers.

filterSets.name: Internationalization
filterSets.info: code flaws having to do with internationalization and locale

filterSets.name: Clone Implementation Rules
filterSets.info: The Clone Implementation ruleset contains a collection of rules that find questionable usages of the clone() method.

filterSets.name: String and StringBuffer Rules
filterSets.info: These rules deal with different problems that can occur with manipulation of the class String or StringBuffer.

filterSets.name: Optimization Rules
filterSets.info: These rules deal with different optimizations that generally apply to performance best practices.

filterSets.name: Bad practice
filterSets.info: Violations of recommended and essential coding practice. Examples include hash code and equals problems, cloneable idiom, dropped exceptions, Serializable problems, and misuse of finalize. We strive to make this analysis accurate, although some groups may not care about some of the bad practices.

filterSets.name: Java Logging Rules
filterSets.info: The Java Logging ruleset contains a collection of rules that find questionable usages of the logger.

filterSets.name: Code Size Rules
filterSets.info: The Code Size Ruleset contains a collection of rules that find code size related problems.

filterSets.name: Import Statement Rules
filterSets.info: These rules deal with different problems that can occur with a class' import statements.

filterSets.name: Basic Rules
filterSets.info: The Basic Ruleset contains a collection of good practices which everyone should follow.

filterSets.name: J2EE Rules
filterSets.info: These are rules for J2EE

filterSets.name: Migration Rules
filterSets.info: Contains rules about migrating from one JDK version to another. Don't use these rules directly, rather, use a wrapper ruleset such as migrating_to_13.xml.

filterSets.name: Correctness
filterSets.info: Probable bug - an apparent coding mistake resulting in code that was probably not what the developer intended. We strive for a low false positive rate.

filterSets.name: Jakarta Commons Logging Rules
filterSets.info: The Jakarta Commons Logging ruleset contains a collection of rules that find questionable usages of that framework.

filterSets.name: Braces Rules
filterSets.info: The Braces Ruleset contains a collection of braces rules.

filterSets.name: Unused Code Rules
filterSets.info: The Unused Code Ruleset contains a collection of rules that find unused code.

filterSets.name: Coupling Rules
filterSets.info: These are rules which find instances of high or inappropriate coupling between objects and packages.

filterSets.name: Naming Rules
filterSets.info: The Naming Ruleset contains a collection of rules about names - too long, too short, and so forth.

filterSets.name: JUnit Rules
filterSets.info: These rules deal with different problems that can occur with JUnit tests.

filterSets.name: Strict Exception Rules
filterSets.info: These rules provide some strict guidelines about throwing and catching exceptions.

filterSets.name: Code Duplication
filterSets.info: This encompasses various degrees of code duplication, from copy-and-paste to code only differing in variable names or constants

filterSets.name: Dodgy
filterSets.info: code that is confusing, anomalous, or written in a way that leads itself to errors. Examples include dead local stores, switch fall through, unconfirmed casts, and redundant null check of value known to be null. More false positives accepted. In previous versions of FindBugs, this category was known as Style.

filterSets.name: JavaBean Rules
filterSets.info: The JavaBeans Ruleset catches instances of bean rules not being followed.

filterSets.name: Multithreaded correctness
filterSets.info: code flaws having to do with threads, locks, and volatiles

filterSets.name: Malicious code vulnerability
filterSets.info: Code that is vulnerable to attacks from untrusted code

filterSets.name: Performance
filterSets.info: code that is not necessarily incorrect but may be inefficient
